author: Umesh Yadav
title: Green transport: Cycle lanes and docking stations set for comeback

organizations.name: the directorate of urban land transport

text:
BENGALURU: The Directorate of Urban Land Transport (DULT) wants to revive the concept of cycle lanes and docking stations in the city , although this could be easier said than done. 

The DULT is preparing a project report on developing a network of cycle lanes in the city as well as identifying locations for docking stations. 

“This time we don't want a flop project and are doing our best for its success, “ said DULT Commissioner Darpan Jain . 

An earlier plan to establish cycle docking stations that was piloted by Kerberon Automations failed to progress because of differences with the Metro Rail authorities. Parxsys Technologies, which installed docking stations at six Metro stations in 2011, gave up and shifted focus to private campuses because of the high annual licencing fee that it has required to pay to Metro Rail. 

TenderSURE projects and Neighbourhood Improvement Plans incorporate cycling lanes that could encourage more people to commute by cycling but the city lacks an overall infrastructure that could make this more feasible. 

DULT wants to provide cycles, lay down cycling lanes and also set up docking stations across the city , Jain said. 

“These point-to-point docking stations will come with smart cards for users and cycles will be given out on an hourly basis,“ he said. 

DULT has planned a pilot project at HSR Layout for a 22-km network of cycling lanes at a cost of about Rs 18.5 crore. 

“There are a good number of cyclists at HSR Layout. 300-400 cyclists use bicycles as a mode of transportation. This is way this place was selected for the pilot project,“ said Kavitha Reddy ,a resident of HSR Layout. 

Syed Haseeb Arfath , a cofounder of Parxsys, said for DULT's plan to succeed, cycling lanes and docking stations should connect every part of the city. 

“The authorities should establish docking stations at every bus stop. If every bus stop and every housing colony has one docking station, commuters won't mind cycling the short distance and taking a bus,“ said Arfath. 

“A city like Bengaluru needs at least 3,000 cycles and 300 docking stations.“
